title: Will there still be dictionaries in 2020?

I was very interested in seeing that you were referring to specializing in customization for publishers, and I was wondering whether you could tell us a bit more about how publishers are looking at customization now.
Alright, well specialization.
I mean, I think I mean in the area of English language learning.
I mean, it's really more moving towards English language using and that there are countless students in English language speaking universities not even in English language speaking countries.
I mean in places like the Netherlands and so on.
Who are studying you know accountancy, environmental science and so on.
So I think that producing resource is specifically to though for those sort of group.
Specialized corpora, specialized word lists and so on is is a possible way of getting those institutions to actually pay money for something which is more specialized.

And I think that the fact that we know that people pay for the Financial Times we know that people paying for Nature magazine and so on gives at least there's a precedent for the idea that for something more specialized people will pay.
Whereas I think for general data, whether it's dictionary data or the Times newspaper which Rupert Murdoch tried to put a paywall around, I don't think that's not going to happen.
